posts.com:
malley's chocolate for superman ice cream if you've never tried it.
cosmic daves subs for a bottle of dave's cosmic sauce. the subs are fine too, but the sauce is really good and i crave it all the time now that i've moved out of ohio.
the foundry in lakewood has the best burgers i've ever eaten in my life, particularly i had a chorizo/beef burger there that was incredible. the wings are good too, lots of flavors to choose from.
close to the foundry is mahalls, which has surprisingly good fried chicken for not being in the south.
and if you want really cheap, boring, plain diner kind of food hit up canary's family restaurant. it's not "good" food, but it's fine and it's dirt cheap.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
sipping on some of "That Camphor Cake" from LP
https://www.liquidproust.com/listing/1188363800/that-camphor-cake-400g
It is a aged white label production sheng cake made sometime in the late 1990's to very early 2000's. Very gnarly looking, lots of stems and large misshapen leaves but the tea is undoubtedly well aged. The cake is aptly titled, camphor is its dominant flavor. Reminds me of moth balls and aromatic cedar with earthy and medicinal undertones. Gives me nostalgic vibes of playing in my grandparents wardrobe as a kid. I was not so sure about this tea the first time I had it, but it seems to have grown on me. Definitely, not an everyday drinker or a tea for everyone but I appreciate having it in my stash.

Question: Any diehards have a strong opinion against any 30sec->1min soaking? I use a metal strainer and rarely let it pass the two minute mark. I can enjoy a trifle strong assam as well, but rarely divert from this incredibly light, floral and mild nepalese variant I never have fund myself infusing more than once and never diverted from using water still boiling in the kettle. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18931036
More than anything you should try and soften your tap water somehow, hard water really mutes the flavor of tea.
Short infusions like that are okay but you might as well brew the same leaves twice or even 3 times if you want to do that.
First brew 1 minute or so, second two minutes, third four minutes (if it's worth doing)
The later brews won't taste the same but you are missing out by brewing the leaves for a short amout of time.
If you want to decide if you think its worth getting some kind of water filter to deal with the hard water buy a gallon of cheap spring water (poland springs is good for this) and try brewing your tea with it to see what the difference in taste is.
I also have really hard water and i got a filter pitcher from pur and that helps a lot, britta ones also work fine.

>>18932772
Like with any citrus, you use their juice and their zest. Experiment with both in substitution with where you'd use orange or lemon zest or juice, being sure to adjust sweetness and acidity for the juice.
https://foodchannel.com/2009/can-i-cook-with-grapefruit-zest
They're also crucial in a lot of cocktail recipes, if you're into that sort of thing. You can just do basic sours with them if you don't want to go all out -- and again, try using the zest in place of other citrus zest in your cocktails.

>>18919002
Reminder that 95% of scotch distilleries are owned by multi-national corporations, import barley from countries overseas such as Turkey and Egypt, do the malting offsite, buy peat from other regions of Britain, use lab-created yeast for their mash, use barrels made from American or Spanish wood, and add caramel coloring to the final product.

The only thing authentic about any particular region or scotch distillery is the water or copper stills, both of which could hardly be said to contribute any unique flavor profile to the scotch over any other distillery.

The only thing that gives a scotch an authentically unique flavor profile that is not imported from elsewhere is the process by which the components are put together, i.e. smoked peat, grain ratios, etc. This is a process, which has nothing to do with utilizing the resources of the terroir.

All of this wouldn't be so bad if it wasn't for the over-insistence that each distillery possesses a unique terroir. French wine for example has much stricter requirements for the definition of something like Champagne. If the grapes don't come from Champagne, it is not Champagne.

You are buying a good that is being sold to you as a goodgoy lifestyle product, like a bottle of Armani cologne. There is nothing uniquely Scottish to a bottle of scotch whisky in 2023. It is a globohomo product that is purposefully aimed toward the same soijaks who buy Bespoke Post and Beard Oil and wax philosophic dilletantism about the "delicious" and "complex" smokey peat flavor of Islay malts while looking down their noses at Speyside drinkers, pretending that Don Draper is "literally me" not knowing they're all part of the same retarded, consoomerist goycattle, drinking the epitome of a fake product.

Scotch drinkers are the worst.

LVMH (French):
Ardbeg, Glenmorangie

Diageo (English):
Johnnier Walker, Talisker, Lagavulin, Caol Ila

Laphroaig, Ardmore, Auchentoshan, Bowmore

Aberlour, Strathclyde, Glenlivet, Scapa, Lomond, Chivas

Bruichladdich, Octomore, Port Charlotte

Bunnahabhain

Dalmore, Jura

That enough for you, faggot? Wow, sure are a lot of authentically, wholly-owned Scottish companies in that list, huh? And you really believe international mega-corporations aren't going to cut corners to fulfill the obligation to their shareholders?

The majority of barley is imported through Port Ellen (owned by Diageo), 80-90% of which is foreign import. It is germinated and malted onsite at Port Ellen. As for the barrels, check the websites of any scotch brands and find me a single one not made with American, Spanish or French oak, I dare you. Caramel coloring is not only a reality of scotch production but actually *sanctioned* by the British government - check the regulations yourself. That authentic peat flavor you bloviate about endlessly can comes from Aberdeenshire - the literal other side of the country from Islay. Considering the distribution of peat worldwide, it would be of no surprise to me if this was imported from Eastern Europe as well.

So that whittles down the contribution of individual distilleries to their copper stills, their water and their process.

Please, enlighten me, what have I said that is *blatantly wrong*? That Champagne is not made in Champagne? Or that multi-billion dollar corporations aren't going to dump a fortune into marketing to losers like you?

>>18929314
You need:
>Chef's knife or gyutō for 80% of kitchen work
>Paring knife for peeling and for finer control
>Serrated bread knife for bread and other things better suited to cutting than a straight edge
>Cleaver for hacking through bones and other very hard foods
>Boning knife for fileting fish

Anything else is either very superfluous or extremely specialized that you probably shouldn't buy it if you're only making one or two specific dishes with it.

>>18929858
I've used the grottiest, shittiest knives to cook with, and very nice ones.
Function is basically identical between 90% of knives of any given blade type (chef, cleaver, santoku, etc). An hour on a whetstone turns any knife into a scalpel, and occasional touch ups with a honing rod keep the edge even on soft mystery meat sheet metal knives for months.

Form is the most important aspect. Its was separates them all apart. And, if you pay more, you can get both easily. Good form and whatever you imagine is going to give you noticeably more function.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18932250
>1:3 ratio of yellow turnip to kennebec (any non waxy potato is kosher) iirc i did 1kg of potatoes and had a 300g turnip
>250ml of heavy cream
>5 garlic cloves minced/microplaned
>tablespoon of kosher salt
>tsp of white pepper
>tsp of black pepper
>tbsp of tallow/butter/lard
>heat cream, minced/planed garlic salt, pep, tallow until almost boiling and transfer to SS bowl
>peel pots and turnups and mandoline/meat slicer/cut as thin as possible like ⅛" into bowl of hot cream
>toss a few times to evenly distribute seasonsings
>either layer in a cake pan of whatever size or layer in a 4" ring mold with foil on the bottom
>if using cake pan fill another full of hot water with a foil on the bottom and weigh down the potato mixture and bake at 400f until fork tender

>ideally fill cake pan 1/3-1/2 at max cause cream boil over, put a baking tray below your cake pans
>if using ring molds use an empty soup can that fits and fill with beans or use a all metal olmypic weight to weigh the can down
>once fork tender after like 30-40 mins unmold/un weigh and bake at 450f for 5 mins to crisp up
thats aboot it

>>18912357

For a while, up until recently I had a very unhealthy hydration routine...well, there was no routine.

I would have a strong coffee when I woke up, go to work, have a diet soda while I was at work...then when I came home have another diet soda (caffeine free this time)....

But the weird thing is I was never THIRSTY. Thus I didn't really "drink" that much fluid or water. But honestly I don't know I didn't suffer more effects from this. It comes out to very little water.

But I have noticed I've gotten very infrequent bowel movements...and that's what disturbed me and inspired me to change my habit. I don't eat too much to begin with, but I think the lack of water slowed everything down...and diet soda is not good for you gut apparently either.

So recently I started to try and make a point of drinking a bottle of water when I wake up, and substituting water wheras before I would drink diet soda.

Does it suck? Yes. But I think it's one of those things where when you have a habit for a long time, you have the initial "shock" of changing the habit, but then have to "rewire" yourself slowly over time.

Basically I have to readapt to drinking plain pure water often. The last few days I've been trying to cut out diet soda entirely. I think it's probably for the best. Time will tell if it leads to any real improvement.

Diet soda is strange in the sense that it's possible to not feel any negative effect at all...but perhaps once it's taken away I will notice positive changes

posts.com:
>>18931288
Fast food is good for anything fried. It saves you the trouble of dealing with large amounts of fry oil, having a deep fryer or mess wok setup, and saves you the waste from breading stuff. Major labor savings here.

Sandwiches (unless fried) are the goto for making at home. Super easy to make, you can keep all the ingredients in the fridge, and if you want it toasted you have plenty of options: oven broiler, toaster oven, air fryer, etc. Microwave is there for heating ingredients if needed.

Hard to make soups are great to do at restaurants. Things like pho, ramen, bisques, and so on. These things take lots of time, so having it made for you is great.

Burgers and steaks should always be made at home. Both fast food and restaurants are fucking you here. They just can't deliver the quality a home cook can, period.

Pizza is definitely a restaurant thing, just because doing it at home requires expensive custom setups to do right. To even compete you need a dedicated pizza oven and then all the proofing equipment and time to do that crap. And the pizza oven only does 1 thing: pizza. Not to mention you have to get super autistic about the process & ingredients. At least a grill makes many good things.

Sushi is one of the other things that is better to leave to a restaurant. I've tried making it myself, and it is definitely harder (and riskier) to do yourself. Not to mention supply issues with finding proper sushi grade fish.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18925914
Competitive eating isn't about being hungry. Actually, being hungry can lessen your chances. The longer you go without food, the more your stomach contracts. The muscles tighten up, and you end up with less room for food. It will relax after you've started eating, as your body realizes what's going on, but by then your brain might already be getting signals of satiation and you'll start to feel full. The key to competitive eating is to cram as much in as possible before your brain catches on. For most people, this is about 20 minutes. The pre-competition exercise for most eaters is to drink a bunch of water to stretch out their stomach and make sure everything is relaxed.

That's not why TG is not respected or competed at by pro gamers. It's because the rules they use are not the ones that have evolved within each game's community to maximize interests of competitiveness, fun, viewer entertainment (thus monetization), accessibility, etc.
>>18931770
That's why they have different categories. OoT has an anything-goes Any% category that uses ACE, but most people want to watch and play some variety of NMG (no major glitches). Same with ALTTP and many (but not all) other major speed games. Your objection is idiotic.

The basic objection you guys have is completely paralleled in Olympic track & field events, which have existed for millennia. Take the javelin throw, for example. A new technique was developed that blew previous records out of the water, but it didn't look like the traditional, martial javelin throw -- thus it was banned. The javelin equipment itself gets handicapped every decade or so because athletes get better and better, such that the best throwers can never exceed 100 meters in the best condition -- thus they can do the throw within the bounds of a standard track stadium. (So how do you compare a record from 1910 to a record from 2010? You don't; and guess what, you don't compare a 100 meter dash record between those years either, or almost any other event besides possibly shot and disc.) Yet Guinness seems to have no problem with putting, say, an Olympian from the 1970s or something as the person with the record for the furthest javelin throw, even though using the same equipment any modern world-class thrower could easily beat him.

There's a ton of Olympic sports like that, and Guinness utterly blows a load in its pants when records are broken there. Rules change and it never seems to note every single step in its books, and the record holders on each step (though Wikipedia seems to have no trouble with this).

>>18932459
Everyone knows you have to cook pork all the way through, even 1st-world quality farmed pork, so it's not surprising that many groups in the Bronze Age would ban eating that and other classes of food altogether based on whatever experiences they may have had with their own cooking traditions. But since the time of Rome onwards the eating of pork was more "ritually unclean" than it was physically "unclean" (at least relative to all food at the time), and certainly nowadays there's only the religious aspect, while claiming any practicality in any place in the world where Judaism/Islam/many other religions have a significant presence is just silly. It's a religious tradition and dogma -- that's it, that's fine, that's part of the deal with religion.

That said, there *are* reasons in the modern world to *not* eat pork, even relative to most other meats. The main arguments are more generalized (feed inefficiency is dwarfed by cows, and general benefits of vegetarianism of course requires a share with a whole range of meats), but specific to pigs is that they've long been known to be very intelligent -- more so than dogs and cats, and kept as pets and work animals in many parts of the world as well -- and we are learning more about their cognitive capabilities every year, most recently the complexity in which they structure their pig society, working together, etc. Yes, scientists are discovering that cows, fish, and chickens are smarter than previously thought as well, but they never started anywhere near the level of pigs, and the new discoveries of intelligence have not been at all as major.

>When ground beef is exposed to air, the ferrous iron in its myoglobin pigment is oxygenated to form a ferrous iron-oxygen complex. Myoglobin is a purplish-red color in its unoxygenated state, and becomes red when the iron complexes with oxygen to form oxymyoglobin. This is what gives fresh beef its red color. But if meat is stored for long periods of time, is stored above proper temperatures, or is exposed to too much air, the ferrous iron loses an electron to become ferric iron. The resulting ferric pigment, known as metmyoglobin, is brown.

>It became gray but doesn't smell bad.
It's fine. Very fresh meat is actually purple. The meat becomes red when it is exposed to oxygen. It turns gray from lack of exposure to oxygen, which would have happened in your fridge after 3 days no matter what.

Fresh ground beef should last at least 5 days in your fridge, unless you bought it at a discount because it was close to expiration. When it goes bad it will definitely start smelling not-so-good, but in my experience is still fine for a couple days after that.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18929116
it's not called like this in the netherlands. we just call it a "gietijzeren pan" which translates to "cast iron pan" but dutch technology is used to create them. this is the explanation.

In the seventeenth century, molds for making cast iron objects were developed in the Netherlands using a special sand mixture. The Englishman Abraham Darby became acquainted with this unknown technique in the Netherlands and introduced it to England. After much experimentation, he succeeded in making rock-solid cast iron pans. Because of the Dutch technique, these pans subsequently became known as Dutch Ovens. A name that has always remained.

>>18931990
Because beginners probably don't know what "dice" means since that's a culinary term and the writers were just making it easier to understand for total newbies who don't know the lingo and I'm fine with that.

>stocks vs broths
there's actually no distinction between the two. you may have heard that stock is made with bones and broth is with meat, but this isn't necessarily true. A better definition would be that stocks are unseasoned and broths are seasoned, regardless of bone or meat content. Stocks are an ingredient not ready to be consumed and broths are in a state that's ready to be consumed, but again there's no general agreement in the culinary world about it. The two terms can be used interchangeably. For example "bone broth" is a common term.

>looks
it says leeks, which are a type of onion.

>Traditional Mirepoix: 8 ounces onion, 4 ounces carrot, 4 ounces celery
This is... partly true. but still written retarded. A classic mirepoix is a ratio of 2 parts onion, 1 part carrot and 1 part celery. But then they stupidly adapted that into an actual amount hahaha. At least they didn't give volumetric measurements for it.

posts.com:
I believe this discussion has devolved into a shit contest. We can be better than that. Let's instead discuss this objectively and analytically.

Instead of discussing "doneness" as if it were exclusive, we can discuss instead the actual factors which combine together to create the property we think of as "doneness".
First, color
second, tenderness
third, the perception of moisture
fourth, the gradient of the above properties through the meat


First reason why we know that "doneness" in the conventional sense that people qualify it with the amount of color as this picture shows>>18931767 is just not real is because that oxymyoglobin that creates the cherry red color has no direct connection to taste or texture. Meat, fresh cut from a butcher will actually be myoglobin- before it has a enough time to interact with oxygen in the air and be oxymyoglobin- and myoglobin will actually be a dark red with a tinge of brown- giving a cut a sometimes almost purpleish red color; and that can carry all the way to changing the look of a "medium" cooked piece of extremely fresh steak. On the other side, a piece of steak that has been aged the iron in the oxymyoglobin will have a chance to oxidize and we end up with the metmyoglobin that is extremely gray; but we all know that aged steak can be wonderful and actually appear to have more moisture- because it isn't moisture, you're just salivating more.

So it's really not about color itself, it's just about the perception. We know that color can look good, or maybe it can put people off. Brown bananas are sweeter and better if you're in the know, but people like yellow as a color over brown. When the steak is heated that myoglobin will go through processes of oxidation at drastically faster rates, changing the color

so lets look at tenderness, tenderness depends on a number of factors including the meat grain, the amount of connective tissue, and the amount and distribution of fat. connective tissue and liquified fat are

I like this. I made a couple.

>Write a recipe using ground beef and honey

Honey Garlic Ground Beef

Ingredients:

1 pound Ground Beef

2 tablespoons Olive Oil

3 cloves Garlic, minced

2 tablespoons Honey

2 tablespoons Soy Sauce

1 teaspoon Fresh Ginger, grated

1/2 teaspoon Salt

1/4 teaspoon Black Pepper

Instructions:

1. Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat.

2. Add the ground beef and cook, breaking it up with a wooden spoon, until it is browned and cooked through.

3. Add the garlic, honey, soy sauce, ginger, salt, and pepper and cook, stirring occasionally, until the garlic is fragrant and the sauce has thickened, about 2 minutes.

4. Serve over hot cooked rice or noodles. Enjoy!

>Write a recipe using stew meat, olives, and sweet potatoes

Moroccan Stew

Ingredients:
2 lbs stew meat
2 cups pitted green olives
2 sweet potatoes, cut into cubes
1 onion, diced
1 red bell pepper, diced
2 cloves garlic, minced
1 teaspoon ground cumin
1 teaspoon ground coriander
1 teaspoon ground ginger
1 teaspoon paprika
1/2 teaspoon cinnamon
2 cups vegetable broth
4 tablespoons olive oil
Salt and pepper

Instructions:

1. Heat the olive oil in a large pot over medium-high heat.

2. Add the stew meat and season with salt and pepper. Cook until the meat is browned on all sides, about 10 minutes.

3. Add the onion, bell pepper, garlic, cumin, coriander, ginger, paprika, and cinnamon. Cook for another 5 minutes, stirring often.

4. Add the vegetable broth and sweet potatoes. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 30 minutes.

5. Add the olives and cook for an additional 10 minutes.

6. Taste and adjust seasoning, if needed. Serve hot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Write a recipe using frog legs, chipotle peppers, and mint

Chipotle Frog Legs with Mint

Ingredients:

-12 frog legs
-2 tablespoons of olive oil
-1-2 chipotle peppers in adobo sauce, finely chopped
-2 cloves of garlic, minced
-1 teaspoon of salt
-1/2 teaspoon of black pepper
-2 tablespoons of freshly chopped mint
-1 lemon, cut into wedges

Instructions:

1. Preheat the oven to 375 degrees Fahrenheit.

2. In a shallow bowl, mix together the olive oil, chipotle peppers, garlic, salt, and black pepper.

3. Dip the frog legs in the mixture and make sure they are evenly coated.

4. Place the frog legs on a baking sheet lined with parchment paper.

5. Bake for 15-20 minutes, or until the legs are cooked through.

6. Once the frog legs are cooked, sprinkle them with the chopped mint and serve with the lemon wedges. Enjoy!

>Write a recipe using whole chicken, apples, and basil

Roast Chicken with Baked Apples

Ingredients:

1 whole chicken

3 apples, diced

1/4 cup fresh basil, chopped

2 tablespoons olive oil

1 teaspoon salt

1 teaspoon black pepper

Instructions:

1. Preheat oven to 375°F.

2. Place chicken in a roasting pan.

3. In a small bowl, mix together diced apples, chopped basil, olive oil, salt and pepper.

4. Spoon the apple mixture into the cavity of the chicken.

5. Place the roasting pan in the preheated oven and bake for 1 hour and 15 minutes, or until chicken is cooked through.

6. Once cooked, remove chicken from the oven and let rest for 10 minutes before serving. Enjoy!

David Foster Wallace's Last Meal

Ingredients:

• 2 tablespoons olive oil
• 1/4 teaspoon salt
• 1/4 teaspoon ground black pepper
• 1/2 cup sliced mushrooms
• 1/2 cup diced onion
• 1/2 cup diced bell pepper
• 1/2 cup diced carrots
• 1/2 cup diced celery
• 2 cloves garlic, minced
• 2 cups cooked black beans
• 2 cups cooked white rice
• 1/2 cup fresh cilantro, chopped
• 2 tablespoons fresh lime juice
• 2 tablespoons fresh oregano, chopped

Instructions:

1. Heat the olive oil in a large pot over medium heat.

2. Add the mushrooms, onion, bell pepper, carrots, celery, and garlic. Cook, stirring often, until the vegetables are tender, about 5 minutes.

3. Add the black beans and rice and cook, stirring occasionally, for 5 minutes.

4. Stir in the cilantro, lime juice, and oregano.

5. Cook for another 5 minutes, stirring occasionally.

6. Taste and adjust seasoning

Instructions:

1. Preheat your oven to 350 degrees F.

2. In a medium bowl, mix together the tuna hearts, mayonnaise, Dijon mustard, garlic powder, salt, and pepper.

3. Spread the tuna mixture onto the frozen waffles and top each one with a piece of cheese.

4. Place the waffles onto a baking sheet and bake in the preheated oven for 10 minutes.

5. Meanwhile, in a small saucepan, heat the beer over medium heat just until it starts to simmer.

6. Remove the waffles from the oven and assemble the sliders with a lettuce leaf, tomato slice, and a spoonful of the beer sauce.

7. Serve the sliders warm and enjoy!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18930816
>Why not? As long as the recipe it generates uses sound quantities of ingredients and I know enough about the dish to proofread the process, why not?
Because real recipes are tested.
>Once you know the fundamentals and the approximate percentages of ingredients one would use, you don’t need a “recipe” anymore.
To make good food, sure. To make great food, you need a recipe where the ingredients and process have all been very fine-tuned (and of course a good recipe gives instructions accounting for inevitable variability in spice and other ingredient quality).

Also, if you're looking for genuine creativity in recipes, an AI won't give you that yet unless it's been guided. Since it's just going by shit it finds online, if pressed to make something unusual, it may put some reasonable process together with random ingredients, but there is zero reason why those ingredients would actually work in harmony together, or even cook properly together.

And if your cooking know-how accounts for all that, then what exactly is the AI doing? Just use a random ingredient generator, or a random snobby-sounding recipe generator, and use that to guide your next inspiration.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18930800
>>18932701
The steps are out of order. That's an easy tweak for someone making a specialized recipe AI and not just using ChatGPT, but no novice can follow that recipe, since it's telling you to mix the sauce in the middle of a 2-minute stir fry.

Also, soy sauce and PB don't mix well alone. First, you need emulsified PB for it to mix at all in that bowl -- no all-natural PB. Second, you have to heat it up, or add like a teaspoon or two of near-boiling water to get the PB soft and liquidy enough to mix smoothly with the soy sauce. Otherwise, just throw them on the side of the pan and mix them there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18932313
The problem is that gluten is a pretty important part of many flour-based recipes (pasta, pizza/kneaded breads), so you can't just use any powder as a substitute. Not only do you need some sort of gluten substitute, you need stabilizers/emulsifiers as well to get it to work similarly to gluten-containing flour. Even then, it's a pale approximation. I've seen gluten-free "flours" containing powdered egg and ground chickpea as the gluten/protein alternate, with xanthan gum and tapioca powder to stabilize and emulsify, and other fillers like rice flour as the main starch component. If you wanted to make your own, getting just the right mix would take quite a bit of R&D.

Did your doctor diagnose you with celiac disease or NCGI? If the former, there are several flours you can use, but some you have to look for specific gluten-free ones since they can be processed with wheat equipment (oat flour specifically). If the latter, you have much more leeway with the general presence of gluten and don't have to be completely autistic about it, assuming your doctor did the differential diagnosis correctly (he should have done a blinded test on you among other things).

>>18932074
>constantly sickly and frail over a fucking meme.
I've never heard of this as an identified symptom of NCGI, either anecdotal or confirmed.
>he main symptoms in patients with NCGS include abdominal bloating and pain in the upper or lower abdomen, diarrhea, nausea, aphthous stomatitis, alternating bowel habits, and constipation. These symptoms are also common in other functional GI disorders, particularly IBS and functional dyspepsia. ... . In addition to experiencing GI symptoms, patients with NCGS most often experience a complex of extra-intestinal symptoms, including a “foggy mind”, which is described as an inability to concentrate, reduction of mnemonic capabilities, and lack of well-being as well as tiredness, headache, anxiety, numbness, joint/muscle pain, and skin rash/dermatitis.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6182669/
Really the only way to confirm there is *some* form of diet sensitivity going on is the double-blind-placebo-controlled gluten challenge (or equivalent with overlapping diet restrictions like FODMAP). If the doctor didn't do that with you (because it's a pain in the ass to do that would be logistically impossible with every IBS patient), then they didn't make a formal diagnosis, but rather are just having you try a possible treatment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I put spray cheese on almost everything I eat. I've can't remember the last time I've eaten in at a fast food place because they don't have spray cheese as a condiment. Even if it makes more sense for my schedule to eat in at a fast food place, I won't unless I remembered to bring a can of spray cheese in my car, and even then, I'll eat it in the car to save myself the embarrassment of having to show the entire restaurant my spray cheese.

A while back, I had to go to a really fancy restaurant for a family get-together, and I was nearly kicked out by the waitstaff for "ruining the atmosphere" when I put spray cheese on my steak tartare. After nearly getting on my knees while apologizing, they let me stay to finish the meal, but it was extremely uncomfortable, especially since there wasn't anything on the menu that could satisfy my particular palate. I'm pretty sure I could hear some waitresses giggling from the kitchen when I passed by it to go to the bathroom.

Don't get me wrong, I'm not some white trash redneck who can't cook. I really like copying Alton Brown and Adam Rageusa, often to the letter, but no matter what they make, I WILL spray cheese it. I can't live without it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Nonstick:
>Easily scratched and ruined forever
>Toxic chemicals if heated to too high of a temperature
>Loses heat quickly

Steel or Aluminum:
>Dent easily if dropped
>Don't hold heat very well
>Food sticks if using low amounts of fat, which you probably are if you're camping or hiking

Cast iron:
>Can handle some abuse
>Holds heat very well
>Can be placed directly into embers and covered with them (Lid on of course) to act as an oven allowing a larger range of dishes to be made
>Clean up can be done with just some salt and finished by setting it back over the fire to dry and you're good to go

Durability + Different usages.

Holy shit it's identical, you're just skipping the whole point, which is to make sure there's nothing left over on the fucking utensil.

It's a simple concept: a utensil with a lot of surface area means a lot of area that something like honey will stick do. If you're making something (like a sauce) later that needs some liquid sweetener anyway, you can use water to remove all the excess honey from the utensil (or analogous sticky substance for analogous applicable food) because the honey dissolves easily in water. Thus you get virtually zero wasted honey and an easily cleaned utensil. This should not be fucking controversial, yet everybody is hung up on the idea that as soon as water touches something it becomes "dishwater" like a bunch of fucking 5-year-olds.

>>18924203
Traditionally in the US steak was cooked well-done until the 1930's. Because of the Dustbowl (look it up, kids) and rail disruptions it was impossible for the New York steakhouses to get the top-quality beef from Texas and Oklahoma they were used to. The lower quality beef was tough to begin with and some cuts were worse. So the restaurants in New York switched to sirloins as the default and so on.
They also started cooking these leaner cuts medium rare to both take advantage of the lean and to hide the lower quality of the steak itself.
Sauces and such also leaped into use because of this. The UK developed Steak Diane in a similar move to hide the low quality of beef during the worst of teh Depression.
AS the tony nightspots in New York and London adopted these tricks to cover and stretch cheap, low-quality meat it was replicated across a lot of Europe and (especially) the US such that a few generations later the majority of Americans associate 'medium-rare-' with 'high class' to the point they extend it to ridiculous things like hamburgers, massively increasing the risk of food bone pathogens but at least they aren't 'acting lower class', amirite?

There's a reason it's called "well done" and not "overdone". If the meat tastes dry and tough or rubbery then it's overdone, just like it would be with fish or chicken. The point of doing "well done" well is that the cooking is timed precisely to stop when the meat is cooked through. In that sense it arguably requires more skill than to do any other steak preparation, unless you're do it sous vide or something.

tldr: if it's "overdone" it's not "well done". Under, over, over, done.

>>18930967
I'm not saying I don't like it. I love parsnips.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Like all vegetables I cook, I cover parsnips when i cook them. They end up cooking in the steam from their own internal water, and I consider them done when they're totally soft and mushy throughout. By this point some natural caramel will have formed on the bottom of the pan or roasting tray just from the parsnips' own sugar.
People would say cooking them until soft is overcooked, but no, that's just cooked through. If it's still crunchy in the center then that's simply a raw uncooked center. And to get some browning or crisp on the outside I may then turn up the heat, uncover, and let them roast like that until brown.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18928457
I use a masterbuilt electric. Had an old-school charcoal bullet for years, but gave it to my oldest son when he got a place of his own. I am using an electric for now because I smoke frequently and the 'zero lead time' is nice.
I am seriously considering building an actual smokehouse in my yard soon.

I am doing 6 racks of ribs tomorrow for a family party.

The *easy* surefire way to do baby back ribs in a smoker won't give you award-winning ribs, but wil never give you bad ribs. It is the 3-2-1 way
First
>Get ribs to room temp as your smoker heats up. Remove the membrane on the ribs. Put on the rub of your choice.
>Get your smoker to an even 225-230 temp with a lighter pellet like apple, maple, etc. Mesquite can overwhelm BBRs. I like pear or cherry, too
>Once at stable temp put on the ribs and leave them alone for 3 hours in good smoke
>Then pull them off the smoker and thoroughly wrap them in foil and replace. Some people add things like brown sugar, honey, rub, BBQ sause, etc and THEN foil
>Do two more hours wrapped in foil.
Remove the ribs, remove the foil, put ribs back
>Cook 1 more hour
Then remove, let sit for 5-10 minutes, and add BBQ sauce as desire.
Can't fail
>

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The last thing I smoked was baby backs. Simple 321.
>mustard and rib rub overnight, set out to room temp
>boneside down at 2-225° for 3 hours
>remove ribs place meat side down in a bed of brown sugar, butter, more rib rub in foil, seal tightly
>back on smoker for 2 hours
>remove from foil, carefully place bone side down back on smoker
>cook for 1 hour to firm up, basting every 10 min.

I got the Walmart Pitboss, the Lexington 540 for like $180 on clearance

Walmart/Lowes exlcusive pit bosses with this shaped controller all fail. The control boards have gigantic amounts of failures and a ton of people sell 3rd party replacements to fix them.

https://www.amazon.com/FlameSky-Thermostat-Replacement-Temperature-Controller/dp/B08JV5NXXV/

Also get bluetooth, you might think you dont need it, but you do.

>>18928457
Yes, I have 3. Last thing was pulled pork and a ham.

Here is the key: you want to smoke at 225 for most things. You can crank it to 250 for winter temps, but by and large you want to hit 225.

I've done plenty of ribs, and >>18930761
is pretty much right on the money. I just use BBQ sauce in the foil as a shortcut. Oh, and if you overdo it in the foil, you can just leave it a bit longer afterwards to dry it back out.

First part: puts smoke in the meat & build crust
Second foiled part: makes meat steam and get tender. Use bend test to check for doneness (bend ribs in foil to check pliability).
3rd part: for setting/caramelizing sauces and firming meat back up, also puts smoke into sauce

>>18930749
Apple, maple, pecan, peach, orange and cherry are all good woods for pork. Pecan is as bold as you should go. Hickory can work, but apple is always my goto fav.

Electric smokers are great, you get pure wood smoke for the cheapest run cost and tightest temp control. BUT, no smoke ring due to lack of combustion. Highly recommend for beginners.

My arguement isn't that your method is wrong, it is that your method is not applicable in scenarios where the pot just isn't large enough, which would be the case in a number of households. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18932133
>Depending on the surface area available you risk burning some pieces of meat (and/or aromatics) to achieve browning on others due to the fact that the aromatics are in the way eating up surface area
Stirring constantly eliminates this problem. A larger pan/pot makes it easier but as long as you can reasonably stir everything then you can saute the meat and vegetables at the same time and achieve browning.

my main point though is that, even if you saute the meat and vegetables separately but in the same pan, doing the meat first then the veg will result in burnt fond, even if the vegetables will release water and deglaze the pan at first. Once that water evaporates so the veg will start gaining some color, the meat fond will start burning because it was already browned before the veg went in.

>>18930531
Eels are a seriously vulnerable fishing population, so really be careful and check the farming method on any eel you buy. If it's not labelled, google the label on the can. Most cheap Asian products will not be sustainably farmed (i.e., they wild-catch the juveniles, which is an extremely vulnerable, finite, and poorly -- if at all -- understood breeding population).
Look for U.S. North Carolina wild caught, or any indoor farmed.
https://www.seafoodwatch.org/recommendations/search?query=%3Afree%3Beel%7Call
The importance of this isn't just to "save duh eels" -- it's that there is literally no substitute for how deliciously fatty unagi is, and the migratory populations all move in discrete, singular groups that are vulnerable to catastrophic failure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18932197
There exists closed tank farming. It can meet current demand and consumption, but has higher start-up costs, and like most farming promises low profits, and thus is an unattractive investment in Asian markets where regulatory enforcement might be lax. For the European eel, England and the continent already have fitted most of their river structures with pathways more migratory fish. Eels are not in the long term threatened directly by human consumption demand alone, but in the short term people need to shell out the additional money on sustainable.options to not only reduce demand for unsustainable fishing, but to show that the extra investment in sustainable operations is worth it.

But when you're talking about problems of human population and overconsumption, seafood is far down on the list of concerns since it's actually realistically solvable (food preferences and even fashions are actually extremely malleable in the medium term, especially if you can manipulate prices in key market through taxes subsidies)

>>18931124
Tilapia's nutrition isn't as great as the benefits touted by the oily fish including the salmonids, but it's still a fish that's a better source of omega 3s than other meats, whether wild or farmed.

Regarding cooking, I agree that it's a pretty tasteless white fish, but if you just need that texture then there are plenty of recipes for which it can be essential.

The most basic way I know of to prepare bland cheap tilapia filets is to rub both sides generously with ground cumin and fry that up in like 2 T of oil. Cumin is quite cheap in the bulk containers and will act as both flavoring and similar to flouring. Salt and pepper to serve, plus lemon and maybe olive oil to taste is as simple as it gets. Look also for filets with a good bit of skin or ask the fish dude to leave the skin on when they scale it -- in the West they remove the skin from a lot of the pre-cut filets, and the skin being mostly fat will add a lot of flavor (that's why they love it in Asia).
